1118304822422323200.text: But how do we solve interoperability?  Trustless atomic txs.

1118304821000511488.text: We also have Layer 2! Lightning network, Raiden, state channels, side chains. Off chain structures designed to solve problems on Layer 1.

1118304819909885958.text: We have Layer 1 protocols - Bitcoin, altcoins, Ethereum, the ICO boom and bust ... at this point we know Layer 1 has some limitations: it’s slow with limited scale, there are high tx fees, insufficient interoperability. 1118296860513447936.text: Bonding curve - automatic market making mechanism. Instead of matching a buyer with seller, you buy or sell to a contract. Automatic liquidity. No scarcity, but it gets expensive. Note the minimum buyback function - incentive to buy and hold.pic.twitter.com/bDwqdPG4Et

Teams might deploy 1 contract to all shards, or L2 might help sync. Lots of research being done by top teams

1101286598027735040.text: There might be a #defi shard - shards that attract other kinds of similar applications building off of network effects

1101286266744856577.text: Q&A - contract yanking? Changing shards? There’s no concept of load balancing - If your shard has a ton of txs you might have you move to another shard without as much volume. Difs in gas prices. Some cost - ~ cost of redeploying contracts plus a bit more

1101285120533766144.text: Where are we today? Eth1x in progress, phase 0 testnet eta late 2019, phase 1 eta early 2020, phase 2 late 2020/ early 2021 (dev from eth 1x carries over), phase 3 2021 or later. Who’s working on it? 8+ teams... a lot of people!

1101283986280730624.text: Phase 3 - light clients - minimize on chain data by moving as much as possible off chain.

1101283636912054289.text: Phase 2 - state execution, cross shard txs, concept of contract yanking or migrating shards. Dev likely to start early 2020

1101283178575208454.text: Shard chains - 1024 shards - independent of each other but they all have a link to beacon chain (backbone of system). No meaningful state execution yet.

1101282605301936128.text: Beacon - validator registry, reward & penalties, PoS finalization, shuffling/ randomness. Become a validator by generating an eth2.0 Val & withdrawal address, send 32 ETH deposit. Validator proposes blocks and creates attestations of the world

1101281416632041472.text: Eth roadmap... includes eth1x, phase 0 beacon chain (PoS and one way deposit), phase 1 (shards), phase 2 (starts to resemble eth1 w smart contracts, shards evm).. migration begins?, phase 3 (light clients)pic.twitter.com/EGvthIhby2

1085764766751178752.text: 6/ PMs work well in cases in which there are an arbitrary number of payments being sent to an arbitrary number of Recipients, which are completing some work that is continuous and can be split into tiny pieces. I’m excited to see them used across more projects and use cases

1085764765413040128.text: 8/ - And @LivepeerOrg writes about them in their Streamflow proposal herehttps://github.com/livepeer/wiki/blob/master/STREAMFLOW.md#probabilistic-micropayments …

1085764763458646017.text: 5/ With 1 on-chain tx, a Recipient can claim/settle as many winning tickets as it wants . A recipient can also settle payments strategically, s.t. gas costs remain at a small fixed % overhead.

1085764762682707968.text: 4/ Only a small % of these tickets “win” and can be cashed in by the Recipient. If a ticket "loses", it still contains proof the Recipient is being paid. The payment amt and % of winners can be set s.t., in the long run, the Recipient is paid the correct amount for work done

1085764761101455360.text: 3/ PMs work more efficiently. With PMs, each Sender makes 1 on-chain tx to put a deposit in escrow. For each small task done by a Recipient (i.e., a segment of video transcoded), the Sender signs an off-chain ticket  (a cryptographic data structure w/ payment data).

1085764759633289217.text: 2/ On-chain payments per task are a non-starter (!). Payment channels are also inefficient. For each Sender-Recipient, 4 on-chain txs are req. to open and close each channel. In some cases, high gas costs may exceed the payment, esp if only a tiny piece of work has been done.

1085764758723354624.text: 1/ First, a general use case: many Senders need to send a Recipient payments for completing a series of continuous, granular tasks such as transcoding video , bandwidth provision , and energy transmission.

1085764757964185600.text: 0/ Been reading a lot about #ProbabilisticMicropayments (PMs) over the past few weeks, and believe they deserve more attention in the crypto space. A thread:
